levels.4: Articulates insights into own cultural rules and biases with depth and clarity.
levels.3: Recognizes new perspectives about own cultural rules and biases.
levels.2: Identifies own cultural rules and biases but with minimal depth.
levels.1: Shows minimal awareness of own cultural rules and biases.

levels.4: Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of cultural worldview frameworks.
levels.3: Demonstrates adequate understanding of cultural worldview frameworks.
levels.2: Demonstrates partial understanding of cultural worldview frameworks.
levels.1: Demonstrates minimal understanding of cultural worldview frameworks.

levels.4: Interprets intercultural experience from multiple perspectives and acts in supportive ways.
levels.3: Recognizes feelings of others and responds appropriately.
levels.2: Identifies feelings of others but struggles to respond appropriately.
levels.1: Expresses own perspective without recognizing feelings of others.

levels.4: Skillfully adapts language and behaviors to context and audience.
levels.3: Adapts language and behaviors to context and audience with minor lapses.
levels.2: Attempts to adapt language and behaviors but with limited effectiveness.
levels.1: Rarely adapts language or behaviors to context and audience.

levels.4: Asks complex questions and seeks out and articulates answers to these questions that reflect multiple cultural perspectives.
levels.3: Asks deeper questions about other cultures and seeks out answers.
levels.2: Asks simple or surface questions about other cultures.
levels.1: States minimal interest in learning about other cultures.
